title: Time-Series Decomposition with BASTION
text: Bayesian Adaptive Seasonality Trend decomposition Incorporating Outliers Noise (BASTION) Bayesian framework decomposing time series trend multiple seasonality. Existing decomposition methods, though widely used, exhibit several limitations: Difficulty adapting abrupt changes trend, Lack robustness outliers heteroskedasticity Absence uncertainty quantification, Inability accommodate multiple seasonal patterns, BASTION first Bayesian method effectively address challenges unified framework.

title: Time-Series Decomposition with BASTION
text: Let’s consider following simulated data : Figure 1: Simulated Data abrupt changes trend, outliers, heteroskedastic noise term. BASTION fitted along three existing methods comparison: TBATS (Alysha M. De Livera & Snyder, 2011) MSTL (Bandara et al., 2021) STR (Dokumentov & Hyndman, 2022). One defining characteristic simulated data see presence abrupt changes trend occur around t = 74, 156, 239. Figure 2: true trend componenet drawn black estimated trend component TBATS, MSTL, STR, BASTION drawn blue. Dotted lines represent 95 percent confidence intervals TBATS credible regions STR. Notice BASTION provides: Adaptive Trend Estimate: BASTION successfully capture abrupt changes resulting lowest mean squared error (MSE), also providing smooth estimate. Robust Uncertainty Quantification: BASTION achieves 98 percent empirical coverage based 95% credible region. existing decomposition method provides uncertainty quantification STR (Dokumentov & Hyndman, 2022), confidence interval provided STR vastly -covers 72.4 percent empirical coverage.
code: #devtools::install_github("Jasoncho0914/BASTION") library(BASTION) #running below takes about 5 minutes total. set.seed(40) BASTION_sim = fit_BASTION(y = y[,"y"],                       Ks = list(7,30),                       Outlier = TRUE,                       cl= 0.95,                       obsSV = "SV",                       nsave = 2000,                       nburn = 4000) y_ts <- forecast::msts(y[,"y"], seasonal.periods=c(7,30)) TBATS = forecast::tbats(y_ts) TBATScomp = forecast::tbats.components(TBATS) STR = stR::AutoSTR(y_ts,robust = TRUE,confidence = 0.95) MSTL = forecast::mstl(y_ts)

text: Let’s apply BASTION real-world dataset analyzing average daily electricity demand (measured megawatts per hour) New York State. dataset, sourced New York Independent System Operator (NYISO) via U.S. Energy Information Administration ((EIA), 2024), exhibits complex long-term trend, intricate seasonal patterns, heteroskedastic noise. time-series decomposition, demonstrate BASTION effectively reveals underlying patterns otherwise obscured noise. Figure 3: Daily average electricity demand New York State July 1, 2015, June 30, 2024. data represent average hourly electricity demand day, aggregated hourly observations. Based raw data, see following: Seasonal Patterns: Electricity demand peaks summer months due air conditioning rises winter heating needs. Heteroskedasticity: Variability higher summer winter (periods peak demand) lower spring fall (stable usage). Long-Term Trends: significant long-term trend observed electricity demand. slight overall decline may indicate influence improved energy efficiency years.

text: Figure 4: Decomposition trend, weekly seasonality, yearly seasonality, volatility using BASTION daily average electricity demand July 1, 2015, June 30, 2024. Dark grey regions represent 95% credible intervals. enhance clarity, weekly seasonality displayed period April 1, 2016, July 1, 2016. Notice BASTION reveals patterns apparent raw data: noticeable dip observed winter 2015–2016, driven warmer--usual winter caused strong El Niño effect, reduced heating needs. January 2016 April 2016, electricity demand steadily increased, likely due colder--usual spring early 2016 extended heating needs. summer 2016, electricity demand peaked, reflecting increased air conditioning usage one hottest summers record. noticeable dip late 2019 likely reflects impact COVID-19-related shutdowns. addition yearly seasonal pattern driven weather, weekly pattern reveals electricity demand steady weekdays decreases weekends, consistent common usage patterns. BASTION’s time-varying volatility estimate highlights heteroskedasticity noise term, volatility also exhibiting seasonal patterns. Higher volatility observed winter months, lower volatility occurs summer, closely aligning yearly seasonality pattern. BASTION uniquely models volatility directly, providing insights decomposition methods .
code: library(BASTION) set.seed(4) BASTION_electric <- fit_BASTION(y = NYelectricity$Demand..MW.,                                 Ks = list(7,365),                                 Outlier = TRUE,                                 sparse = TRUE,                                 obsSV = "SV",                                 nsave = 5000,                                 nburn = 5000) elec_ts = forecast::msts(NYelectricity$Demand..MW.,seasonal.periods = c(7,365)) STR_elec = stR::AutoSTR(elec_ts,confidence = 0.95) TBATS_elec = forecast::tbats(elec_ts,use.trend = FALSE,seasonal.periods = c(7,365)) TBATScomp_elec = forecast::tbats.components(TBATS_elec) MSTL_elec = forecast::mstl(elec_ts)

title: Decomposition of time series data with Bayesian Adaptive Seasonality Trend Decomposition Incorporating Outlier and Noise (BASION) — fit_BASTION
text: y numeric vector T x 1 vector time series observations Ks list values containing seasonal periods X matrix additional covariate regression (default NULL) Outlier logical flag (default FALSE) model outlier cl scalar (0,1) confidence leve (default 0.95) sparse logical flag (default FALSE) induce additional shrinkage trend estimate obsSV options modeling error variance. must one following: const: Constant error variance time points. SV: Stochastic Volatility model. nchains integer scalar number chains MCMC sampling (default 2) nsave integer scalar (default = 1000); number MCMC iterations record nburn integer scalar (default = 1000); number MCMC iterations discard (burn-) nskip integer scalar (default = 4); number MCMC iterations skip saving iterations, .e., save every (nskip + 1)th draw verbose logical; report extra information progress true. Defaults FALSE save_samples logical; save return posterior samples components true. Default FALSE

title: Decomposition of time series data with Bayesian Adaptive Seasonality Trend Decomposition Incorporating Outlier and Noise (BASION) — fit_BASTION
text: list providing summarized posterior estimates: p_means: matrix containing posterior means observed data (y) decomposed component: Trend, Seasonality, Outlier, applicable. Trend_sum: matrix containing posterior mean 95% credible interval trend estimate. Seasonal"k"_sum: matrix containing posterior mean 95% credible interval seasonal estimate, "k" determined input. Outlier_sum: matrix containing posterior mean 95% credible interval outlier component.

title: Decomposition of time series data with Bayesian Adaptive Seasonality Trend Decomposition Incorporating Outlier and Noise (BASION) — fit_BASTION
text: (returned save_samples = TRUE) list containing MCMC samples relevant parameters: beta_combined: Posterior samples Trend + Seasonality. beta: Posterior samples component excluding remainder. obs_sigma_t2: Posterior samples variance observation equation. evol_sigma_t2: Posterior samples evolution error term. remainder: Posterior samples remainder term. yhat: Posterior samples signal + error term.
